title: Technology and Digital Communication
learningObjectives: Learn vocabulary related to computers, smartphones, and the internet
Understand how to talk about technology and digital devices
Practice discussing social media and online communication
Recognize common technology problems and solutions

sections.title: Technology in Daily Life
sections.content: Technology is everywhere in modern life. We use computers, smartphones, and the internet every day for work, communication, and entertainment. Learning technology vocabulary in English is essential because most technology terms are in English. This lesson will help you talk about devices, apps, and online activities confidently.

sections.title: Common Devices and Hardware
sections.content: A 'computer' or 'laptop' is used for work and browsing the internet. A 'smartphone' is a mobile phone with internet access. A 'tablet' is between a phone and computer in size. Important parts include: the 'screen' (display), 'keyboard' (for typing), 'mouse' (for clicking), and 'charger' (for battery power). You 'turn on' or 'power on' devices, and 'turn off' or 'shut down' when finished.

sections.title: Internet and Applications
sections.content: The 'internet' or 'web' connects computers worldwide. A 'website' is a page on the internet. A 'browser' (like Chrome or Safari) lets you visit websites. An 'app' or 'application' is a program on your phone or computer. You 'download' apps from an app store. 'Wi-Fi' is wireless internet. When you 'log in', you enter your username and password. 'Email' is electronic mail for sending messages.

sections.title: Social Media and Communication
sections.content: Social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter let people share photos, videos, and messages. You 'post' content, 'like' or 'comment' on others' posts, and 'follow' people you're interested in. 'Messaging apps' like WhatsApp let you send instant messages. A 'video call' lets you see and talk to someone online. Remember to be careful about 'privacy' - don't share personal information with strangers online.

sections.title: Technology Conversations
sections.content:
Example 1: TECH PROBLEM - 'My computer won't turn on. I think the battery is dead.'

Example 2: ASKING FOR HELP - 'Could you help me download this app? I'm not sure how.'

Example 3: SHARING CONTACT - 'What's your email address? I'll send you the document.'

Example 4: INTERNET ISSUES - 'The Wi-Fi isn't working. Can you check the router?'

sections.title: Digital Literacy
sections.content: Technology vocabulary is important in today's world. Learn the names of devices and their parts. Practice talking about apps, websites, and social media. When you have a tech problem, describe it clearly: 'My phone won't charge' or 'I can't connect to Wi-Fi'. Remember to stay safe online - use strong passwords and protect your privacy. Technology changes fast, so keep learning new terms!

keyVocabulary.definition: To copy data from the internet to your device
keyVocabulary.example: I need to download this app on my phone.

keyVocabulary.definition: To send data from your device to the internet
keyVocabulary.example: Can you upload the photos to the cloud?

keyVocabulary.definition: A program used to access the internet
keyVocabulary.example: I use Chrome as my web browser.

keyVocabulary.definition: A secret code to access your accounts
keyVocabulary.example: Make sure your password is strong and secure.
Is there free Wi-Fi in this café?

keyVocabulary.definition: To add power to a battery
keyVocabulary.example: I need to charge my phone - the battery is low.

grammarPoints.explanation: Many technology actions use specific verbs or phrasal verbs.
examples: turn on/off - Turn on your computer.
log in/out - Log in to your account.
sign up - Sign up for a new account.
shut down - Shut down your laptop before traveling.
plug in - Plug in the charger.
commonMistakes: Confusing 'open' and 'turn on': 'Open the computer' ❌ → 'Turn on the computer' ✓
Using 'close' instead of 'shut down' for computers

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'won't' (will not) or 'doesn't work' to describe problems. Use 'can't' for inability.
examples: I can't connect to the internet.
commonMistakes: Using present continuous incorrectly: 'My phone isn't turning on' (less common)
Forgetting 'the' with specific devices: 'Wi-Fi doesn't work' ✓
